etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in Journal of the Chemical Society. From sito- + -sterol, after German Sitosterin (R. Burián 1897, in Monatshefte f. Chemie 18 552; from ancient Greek σῖτος grain, bread + -sterin (in German Phytosterin))

definitions: Any of several closely similar waxy sterols found widely in plant tissues and resembling cholesterol in structure, originally isolated from wheatgerm oil; specifically the most common such substance, "β-sitosterol" (also called cinchol).

notes.text: Mostly denoting isomers of chemical formula C₂₉H₅₀O. Before 1926 considered to be a single substance; the isomers are now often distinguished by a prefixed Greek letter.
